# Dam Safety Program in California

## Overview
- DWR Division of Safety of Dams
- Regulates 1,200+ dams
- Inspection and oversight
- Construction and alteration review

## Jurisdictional Dams

### Criteria
- Height >25 feet, OR
- Storage >50 acre-feet, OR
- High hazard potential

### Exemptions
- Federal dams (Bureau of Reclamation, USACE)
- Some farm ponds
- Debris basins

## Inspection Program

### Annual Inspections
- DSOD staff inspection
- Visual assessment
- Instrumentation review
- Documentation

### Comprehensive Inspections
- More detailed periodic review
- Subsurface evaluation
- Seismic assessment
- Spillway adequacy

## Dam Owner Responsibilities

### Required Actions
- Maintain dam properly
- Report problems immediately
- Emergency Action Plan
- Allow inspections

### Emergency Action Plans (EAPs)
- Inundation maps
- Notification procedures
- Evacuation information
- Regular updates and exercises

## High Hazard Dams

### Classification
- Based on potential consequences
- Not dam condition
- Downstream population/infrastructure

### Enhanced Requirements
- More frequent inspection
- Detailed EAPs
- Risk-informed decision making

## Key Resources
- [Division of Safety of Dams - DWR](https://water.ca.gov/Programs/All-Programs/Division-of-Safety-of-Dams)

# Water Quality Standards and Criteria

## Types of Standards

### Water Quality Objectives
- California term for standards
- Set in Basin Plans
- Protect beneficial uses

### Beneficial Uses
- Municipal and domestic supply
- Agricultural supply
- Industrial supply
- Recreation
- Fish and wildlife
- Others

## How Standards Are Set

### Federal Role
- EPA publishes criteria
- States must meet minimum
- States can be more stringent

### State Role
- Adopt in Basin Plans
- Site-specific standards
- Implementation procedures

## Types of Criteria

### Numeric Criteria
- Specific concentration limits
- Example: 10 mg/L nitrate MCL
- Measurable and enforceable

### Narrative Criteria
- Descriptive standards
- Example: "Free from toxic substances"
- Requires interpretation

## Antidegradation

### Policy
- Maintain existing quality
- Special protection for high-quality waters
- Allow some degradation if justified

### Tiers
- Tier 1: Existing uses protected
- Tier 2: High quality waters
- Tier 3: Outstanding National Resource Waters

## Variances

### When Available
- Cannot meet standard
- Highest attainable use identified
- Time-limited
- EPA approval required

- [Plans and Policies](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/plans_policies/)
- [Water Quality Goals](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/water_quality_goals/)

# Stormwater Capture and Reuse

## Why Capture Stormwater?

### Benefits
- New local supply
- Reduce runoff pollution
- Groundwater recharge
- Flood mitigation

### California Opportunity
- Average 10-15 MAF runoff
- Most flows to ocean
- Capture potential significant

## Capture Methods

### Regional Scale
- Spreading basins
- Large detention basins
- Flood control reservoirs
- Stream/river diversion

### Distributed Scale
- Green infrastructure
- Bioswales
- Rain gardens
- Permeable pavement

### Site Scale
- Rain barrels
- Cisterns
- On-site detention

## Regulatory Framework

### Permits
- No permit typically for capture
- May need permit for large diversions
- Water rights considerations

### MS4 Permit Credits
- Capture may satisfy permit requirements
- LID requirements
- Volume reduction credits

## Funding

### State Funding
- Prop 1 stormwater grants
- Integrated regional planning
- Multi-benefit projects

### Local Funding
- Stormwater fees
- Prop 218 considerations
- Utility rates

# Climate Change and California Water

## Projected Impacts

### Precipitation Changes
- More variable year-to-year
- More extreme wet and dry years
- Timing shifts earlier
- More rain, less snow

### Temperature Effects
- Earlier snowmelt
- Reduced snowpack storage
- Higher evapotranspiration
- Longer dry season

### Sea Level Rise
- Delta salinity intrusion
- Coastal aquifer impacts
- Infrastructure vulnerability
- Flood risk increase

## Adaptation Strategies

### Supply Diversification
- Recycled water expansion
- Desalination where appropriate
- Groundwater storage
- Regional coordination

### Demand Management
- Conservation as permanent ethic
- Efficiency standards
- Water budgets
- Pricing signals

### Infrastructure Adaptation
- Flexible operations
- Improved forecasting
- System interconnections
- Resilience investments

## State Response

### California Climate Adaptation Strategy
- Cross-sector coordination
- Regular updates
- Regional guidance

### Water Plan Integration
- Climate scenarios in planning
- Vulnerability assessments
- Adaptation recommendations

# Water and Land Use Planning

## SB 610 and SB 221

### SB 610 (Water Supply Assessments)
- Required for large projects
- 500+ residential units or equivalent
- Verify 20-year water supply
- Before project approval

### SB 221 (Written Verification)
- Subdivision map approval
- Verify sufficient water supply
- 500+ units
- Written verification from supplier

## General Plan Water Element

### Requirement
- Optional but recommended
- Address water supply
- Coordinate with UWMP
- Long-term planning

## Groundwater and Land Use

### SGMA Connection
- GSPs consider land use
- Land use affects recharge
- Coordination required
- Well permitting

### Local Ordinances
- Well construction standards
- Setbacks and protection zones
- Recharge area protection

## Flood Hazard

- Evacuation routes

# Aquifer Storage and Recovery (ASR)

## What is ASR?
- Inject treated water into aquifer
- Store during wet periods
- Recover during dry periods
- Water banking underground

## How It Works

### Injection
- Treat water to drinking water standards
- Inject through wells
- Water spreads through aquifer
- Creates storage "bubble"

### Recovery
- Pump back through same or nearby wells
- Typically recover 60-80%
- Some loss to aquifer (OK)
- Improves local groundwater

## Regulatory Requirements

### Permits Needed
- Underground injection control permit
- RWQCB oversight
- Well construction permits
- May need water rights

### Water Quality
- Must meet drinking water standards
- Protect aquifer quality
- Monitoring required
- May need treatment for recovery

## California Projects

### Examples
- Orange County Water District
- Calleguas Municipal Water District
- Various municipal utilities

## Benefits

### Advantages
- Local storage
- Drought resilience
- Uses existing infrastructure
- Less evaporation than surface storage

### Considerations
- Requires suitable aquifer
- Well and pump costs
- Water quality compatibility
- Recovery percentage varies

# Cross-Connection Control Program

## What is Cross-Connection?
- Physical link between potable and non-potable water
- Allows backflow into drinking water supply
- Serious public health risk

## Types of Backflow

### Backsiphonage
- Negative pressure in supply
- Siphons contamination backward
- From main breaks, high demand

### Backpressure
- Higher pressure in non-potable
- Pushes contamination into supply
- From pumps, boilers, elevation

## Prevention Devices

### Air Gap
- Physical separation
- Highest protection
- Required for high hazards

### Reduced Pressure Zone (RPZ)
- For high hazard
- Check valves with relief
- Annual testing required

### Double Check Valve Assembly
- For moderate hazard
- Two check valves
- Annual testing

### Atmospheric Vacuum Breaker
- Simple backsiphonage protection
- Limited applications
- Lowest level protection

## Program Requirements

### Water System Responsibilities
- Written program
- Survey customers
- Require appropriate protection
- Testing and recordkeeping

### Customer Responsibilities
- Install required devices
- Annual testing
- Repairs when needed
- Submit test reports

# Water Loss Management

## Why Water Loss Matters

### Types of Loss
- Real losses (leaks in system)
- Apparent losses (meter error, theft)
- Unbilled authorized (fire fighting, flushing)

### Impact
- Wasted treated water
- Revenue loss
- Energy waste
- Environmental impact

## California Requirements

### SB 555 (2015)
- Annual water loss audits
- Standardized methodology
- Submit to State Water Board
- Urban water suppliers

### Performance Standards
- Developing standards for real loss
- Volumetric performance
- Based on AWWA methods

## Water Audit Process

### AWWA Audit Method
- System input volume
- Authorized consumption
- Water losses calculated
- Validated audit

### Data Needed
- Master meter data
- Customer meter data
- Billing records
- System characteristics

## Reducing Water Loss

### Real Loss Reduction
- Leak detection programs
- Pipeline replacement
- Pressure management
- Active leak control

### Apparent Loss Reduction
- Meter testing and replacement
- Improve meter reading
- Unauthorized use detection
- Billing system improvements

# Emergency Response Planning for Water Systems

## Federal Requirements

### America's Water Infrastructure Act (AWIA)
- Risk and resilience assessment
- Emergency response plan
- Required for systems >3,300
- Certification to EPA

### Timeframes
- Based on system size
- Updates every 5 years
- ERP within 6 months of assessment

## Plan Components

### Risk Assessment
- Identify hazards
- Assess vulnerabilities
- Evaluate consequences
- Prioritize risks

### Emergency Response Plan
- Response actions for threats
- Communication protocols
- Alternative water supplies
- Recovery procedures

## Types of Emergencies

### Natural Disasters
- Earthquakes
- Wildfires
- Floods
- Drought

### Operational Emergencies
- Main breaks
- Treatment failures
- Power outages
- Contamination events

### Security Threats
- Vandalism
- Cyber attacks
- Terrorism
- Intentional contamination

## Coordination

### Who to Coordinate With
- Local emergency management
- Health department
- Fire department
- Law enforcement
- Mutual aid partners

# Tribal Water Rights in California

## Federal Reserved Rights

### Winters Doctrine
- Tribes have reserved water rights
- Date to reservation creation
- Purpose: make reservation livable
- Federal law applies

### PIA Standard
- Practicably Irrigable Acreage
- Common quantification method
- Based on reservation land
- Ongoing legal development

## California Tribal Water

### Unique Situation
- Many small rancherias
- Complex history
- State water law limited applicability
- Federal rights predominate

### Current Issues
- Water quality on reservations
- Groundwater access
- Climate change impacts
- Water supply reliability

## Federal Programs

### EPA Tribal Programs
- Treatment as state (TAS)
- Water quality standards
- Funding programs
- Technical assistance

### IHS (Indian Health Service)
- Water and sanitation facilities
- Technical assistance
- Funding for water systems

## State Coordination

### Tribal Consultation
- Executive Order B-10-11
- Government-to-government
- Meaningful engagement
- Cultural resources

### Water Board Programs
- Tribal beneficial uses
- Water quality protection
- Coordination on permits

# Wastewater Biosolids Management

## What are Biosolids?
- Treated sewage sludge
- From wastewater treatment
- Can be beneficially reused
- Regulated material

## Regulatory Framework

### Federal (EPA)
- 40 CFR Part 503
- Standards for biosolids use
- Pollutant limits
- Pathogen requirements

### State (Water Board)
- General Order for biosolids
- Land application requirements
- Reporting requirements

## Use Options

### Land Application
- Agricultural use
- Soil amendment
- Land reclamation
- Most common beneficial use

### Composting
- Mix with bulking agent
- Curing process
- Pathogen reduction
- Public distribution possible

### Incineration
- Thermal destruction
- Energy recovery possible
- Ash disposal needed

### Landfill
- Allowed disposal method
- Last resort typically
- Tipping fees

## Quality Classes

### Class A
- Meets pathogen reduction
- Distribution allowed
- More uses permitted

### Class B
- Site restrictions apply
- Agricultural use with limits
- Access restrictions

## Requirements

### Monitoring
- Pollutant testing
- Pathogen indicators
- Record keeping

### Reporting
- Annual reports
- Application records
- Disposal documentation
